Chapter 2 ‚Äî Fake Data First, Then Fit

Kwan Ho Lee

Source: vignettes/articles/Chapter2.qmd

1 Current Model (what we already fit)

  • Chapter 1 model fits subject-level parameters for each biomarker (y0,t1,y1,Œ±,œÅ)(y_0, t_1, y_1, \alpha, \rho).
  • Within each biomarker: variation is captured by a covariance (Œ£P)(\Sigma_P).
  • Across biomarkers: independence (block-diagonal), i.e.¬†Cov(vec(Œòi))=Œ£P‚äóIB \mathrm{Cov}\!\big(\mathrm{vec}(\Theta_i)\big) = \Sigma_P \otimes I_B

2 Step A ‚Äî Set up

Show R Code
set.seed(123)
library(tidyverse)
library(mvtnorm)   # rmvnorm
library(Matrix)    # kronecker
library(serodynamics)

3 Step B ‚Äî Minimal helpers

4 Step C ‚Äî Choose a ‚Äútruth‚Äù and simulate fake data

Show R Code
# Choose B biomarkers and visit schedule
n_blocks  <- 2
time_grid <- c(0, 7, 14, 30)

# True Œ£P (5√ó5): mild positive correlation among the five latent parameters
sd_p <- c(0.35, 0.45, 0.25, 0.30, 0.25)
R_p  <- matrix(0.25, 5, 5)
diag(R_p) <- 1
sigma_p <- diag(sd_p) %*% R_p %*% diag(sd_p)

# True Œ£B (B√óB): cross-biomarker correlation
R_b <- matrix(c(1, 0.5,
                0.5, 1), n_blocks, n_blocks, byrow = TRUE)
sd_b <- rep(0.6, n_blocks)
sigma_b <- diag(sd_b) %*% R_b %*% diag(sd_b)


# Run simulator
sim <- simulate_multi_b_long(
  n_id      = 5,
  n_blocks  = n_blocks,
  time_grid = time_grid,
  sigma_p   = sigma_p,
  sigma_b   = sigma_b
)

# This long table already matches prep_data() expectations:

sim$data |> dplyr::slice_head(n = 8)

5 Step D ‚Äî Fit the independence model

Show R Code
# If our package is loaded, this is all we need:

sim_tbl <- serodynamics::as_case_data(
  sim$data,
  id_var        = "Subject",
  biomarker_var = "antigen_iso",
  value_var     = "value",
  time_in_days  = "time_days"
)

prepped <- prep_data(sim_tbl)
priors  <- prep_priors(max_antigens = prepped$n_antigen_isos)
fit_v0  <- run_mod(
 data     = sim_tbl,
 file_mod = serodynamics_example("model.jags"),  # our current model
 nchain = 4, nadapt = 1000, nburn = 500, nmc = 500, niter = 5000,
 strat = NA, with_post = TRUE
 )

fit_v0

6 Step E ‚Äî Prepare for Correlated Model

  • In Step D we fit the ‚Äúindependence‚Äù model: each biomarker had its own covariance for the 5 parameters, but biomarkers were assumed independent.
  • Now we allow correlations across biomarkers as well as within biomarkers.
  • Mathematically, we replace the block-diagonal assumption with a Kronecker structure:

Cov(vec(Œòi))=Œ£P‚äóŒ£B \mathrm{Cov}\!\big(\mathrm{vec}(\Theta_i)\big) = \Sigma_P \otimes \Sigma_B

  • Here:
    • Œ£P\Sigma_P = covariance of the 5 parameters (y0,y1,t1,Œ±,œÅ)(y_0, y_1, t_1, \alpha, \rho) within a biomarker.
    • Œ£B\Sigma_B = covariance across biomarkers.
    • The Kronecker product ‚äó\otimes builds a 5B√ó5B5B \times 5B covariance.
  • Implementation plan:
    1. Define priors for Œ£P\Sigma_P and Œ£B\Sigma_B separately (via Wishart distributions).
    2. Build the Kronecker precision matrix T=TB‚äóTP\text{T} = \text{T}_B \otimes \text{T}_P inside JAGS.
    3. Draw each subject‚Äôs stacked parameter vector from this multivariate prior.
    4. Likelihood for observed antibody data is unchanged ‚Äî only the prior covariance differs.

6.1 E.1 Priors for the Correlated Model

We define a helper function prep_priors_multiB() that sets priors for both Œ£P\Sigma_P (within-biomarker) and Œ£B\Sigma_B (across-biomarkers).

  • TP‚àºWishart(Œ©P,ŒΩP)\text{T}_P \sim \text{Wishart}(\Omega_P, \nu_P)
  • TB‚àºWishart(Œ©B,ŒΩB)\text{T}_B \sim \text{Wishart}(\Omega_B, \nu_B)
  • Kronecker precision: T=TB‚äóTP\text{T} = \text{T}_B \otimes \text{T}_P

6.2 E.2 Write the new JAGS model file (Kronecker precision)

This is our model.jags with only one conceptual change:
instead of independent

par[subj,b,]‚àºùí©(Œº.par[b,],prec.par[b,,]) par[\text{subj},\text{b},] \sim \mathcal{N}( \mu.par[\text{b},], \ \text{prec.par}[\text{b},,] ) where b is cur_antigen_iso

we draw all biomarkers at once for a subject with a Kronecker precision:

vec(parsubj,‚ãÖ,‚ãÖ)‚àºùí©(vec(Œºpar),TB‚äóTP). \mathrm{vec}(par_{\text{subj},\cdot,\cdot}) \sim \mathcal{N}\!\big( \mathrm{vec}(\mu_{par}), \ \text{T}_B \otimes \text{T}_P \big).

  • Everything else (transforms, likelihood, measurement precisions) stays as before.
  • We keep our hyperpriors for mu.par (the per-biomarker means), so it plugs right into our current prep_priors().

This is our new model.jags rename as model_ch2_kron.jags

6.2.1 What changed vs.¬†our current model.jags

  • Removed the per-biomarker prec.par[cur_antigen_iso,,] ~ dwish(...) and par[subj,cur_antigen_iso,] ~ dmnorm(mu.par[cur_antigen_iso,], prec.par[cur_antigen_iso,,]).

  • Replaced with one prior per subject on the stacked vector using T=TB‚äóTP\text{T} = \text{T}_B \otimes \text{T}_P

  • Kept our mu.par prior and the likelihood exactly as is.

6.3 E.3: Minimal wrapper so we can keep calling one function

7 What are OmegaP, nuP, OmegaB, nuB ‚Äî and why these defaults?

These are the Wishart hyperparameters for the precision matrices (inverse covariances) used in the Kronecker prior:

  • TP‚àºWishart(Œ©P,ŒΩP)\text{T}_P \sim \text{Wishart}(\Omega_P, \nu_P) ‚Äì within-biomarker parameter precision (5√ó5).
  • TB‚àºWishart(Œ©B,ŒΩB)\text{T}_B \sim \text{Wishart}(\Omega_B, \nu_B) ‚Äì across-biomarker precision (B√óB).

Generally speaking (JAGS Wishart): ùîº[T]‚âàŒΩ‚ãÖŒ©‚àí1\mathop{\mathbb{E}}[\text{T}]\approx \nu \cdot \Omega^{-1} when ŒΩ\nu is not tiny. So smaller diagonal entries in Œ©\Omega imply larger expected precision (i.e., smaller covariance), and vice versa.

7.1 Chosen weakly-informative defaults 

OmegaP_scale = rep(0.1, 5);  nuP = 6
OmegaB_scale = rep(1.0, B);  nuB = B + 1

  • nuP = 6 is just above the dimension (5): proper but not tight.

  • OmegaP = 0.1 * I_5 is diffuse. With small nuP, the prior is wide; data will dominate.

  • nuB = B + 1 is a minimally-informative choice for a B√óB Wishart.

  • OmegaB = I_B centers TauB near identity while letting the data learn cross-biomarker correlation.

These are starting values. Validate with prior predictive checks (simulate parameters ‚Üí curves ‚Üí sanity check ranges).

8 Putting it together

  • Independence model (our baseline): no changes.

  • Correlated model: we supply both the usual priors and the new Kronecker priors:

Run Kronecker model (disabled for now)
# Step 1: simulate fake data (or load real Shigella data)
sim_tbl 

# Step 2: write the new Kronecker model file (once per session/project)
write_model_ch2_kron()

# Step 3: run the unified runner in correlated (Chapter 2) mode
fit_kron <- run_mod(
  data     = sim_tbl,
  file_mod = serodynamics_example("model.jags"),  # baseline model path (unused here)
  file_mod_kron = "model_ch2_kron.jags",          # use the Kronecker model
  correlated = TRUE,                              # <-- key switch
  nchain   = 4, nadapt = 1000, nburn = 500,
  nmc      = 500,  niter = 5000,
  strat    = NA,
  mu_hyp_param = c(1.0, 7.0, 1.0, -4.0, -1.0)     # optional override
)

# Step 4: inspect results (same as with run_mod before)
fit_kron
